title: Waverley; Or, 'Tis Sixty Years Since

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Iwould flatter myself that this is rather good news, since it seems to beno part of a formed insurrection, but an accidental scuffle in which themob have had the worst, and which, like Tranent, Manchester, andBonnymoor, have always had the effect of quieting the people andalarming men of property.[487] The Whigs will find it impossible topermit men to be plundered by a few blackguards called by them thepeople, and education and property probably will recover an ascendencywhich they have only lost by faintheartedness.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: My first appearances were attended to with much expectation ; and I had the satisfaction to find that the first sermon I ever preached, not on trials, which was on the fast day before the sacrament  at Tranent, had met with universal approbation.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: He was carried to the minister's house at Tranent, wdiere he lived till next forenoon.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: In the mean time the Highlanders lay with their right close to Tranent, and had detached some companies down to the churchyard, which was close by a waggon-way which led directly down to our army, and crossed the road leading between Preston and Seaton, where Cope's six or seven pieces of cannon were placed, not above a third of a mile distant from the church.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: But they were too late in marching ; for when they came to St Germains, their scouts, who were chiefly Lords Home and Loudon, brought them intelligence that the rebel army were on their march, on which, after an hour's halt, when, by turning to the left, they might have reached the high ground at Tranent before the rebels, they marched on to that plain before described, now called the field of battle.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: In this camp he could not have been surprised ; and in marching to this ground the road through Tranent was not more distant by 100 yards than that by Seaton.

snippet: 1 [The register of the parish ministers of Prestonpans does notconfirm what is here said about "Mr Cunningham," as thatname does not appear in the list for last century. The referencemay be to the Rev. Charles Cunningham, minister of Tranent,who was ordained in 1740, and died in 1793, in his g2d year.—A.C.F.]2 [The eldest surviving brother of Miss Gray died in 1811—sothat she survived him only 45 years. But there seems to havebeen a still older brother, who died young in the first half of lastcentury.—J. V.]

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: On the same day Mason could have beenfound at Tranent, where he very soon learntthat Lucky Thomson full well knew the morethan ordinary strong hold she had over him.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: Let us now return to Tranent for a while,where there was to be seen a pony, saddled, andwaiting at the door of the inn, from whichpresently emerged the mistress thereof, whomounted and rode away in the direction of Edinburgh.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: She recalled all that thesupposed Prince had said to her, and the moreshe thought over it the more she felt certain ofit, especially when she recollected that the name" His Highness " had given her was the same asone Kate had mentioned to her as being presentwhen the floor fed in at Tranent.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: All trace of gratitude left her face, and in its place something moreof the nature of dogged determination showeditself, all tending to confirm Mistress Rutherfordin her conviction that the baggage was no good,and the sooner she could be packed off to Tranentthe better.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: After awhile came her lodger's turn to speak, and whdetaking good care not to tell his landlady any morethan was necessary to his purpose, he informedher that Kate's grand-aunt was a wicked, worthless woman, who had not only persuaded Kate togo on the stage, but had actually connived at herattempted abduction the previous night, forthe sake of gain, and that it would be but aChristian duty and charity to succour and protect the girl until such time as he could seehis way to take her back to her mother atTranent.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: "Am I also tae lippen tae the messages yebrocht me frae ma niece in Tranent ?"

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: " Ay; I saw you there tae, and I want to kenwhat ye mean tae tell yer freend, as ye ca'her, Mistress Thomson, at Tranent, ma niece,what ye did wi' her dochter, ma grand-niece,last nicht!"

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: " I have done myself the honour of callingupon you, madam, at the request of your niece,Mistress Thomson, of Tranent, whom, I amhappy to say, I left only a few days ago inexcellent health."

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: By her statement, it appeared thatLucky Thomson had an aunt hving in Edinburgh, to whom there came Kate, some sixweeks before, stating that her mother wishedher to remain with her aunt until the countrywas in a less disturbed condition, and moreespecially that the inn at Tranent had been soseriously damaged, in the manner alreadyrecorded, as to be scarcely habitable.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: " Does she hve here in Edinburgh ?"" Na, na, she bides awa' at Tranent."

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: "Ay," she quickly rejoined, "an' ye hadbetter arrest the hale o' Tranent, an' thePans, no tae mention Musselburgh, and Edinburgh, for I'm thinkin' they are as muckletae blame."

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: This information caused Mason to open hiseyes a good deal further than was their normalcondition, as he said, " Your sister, you say, hasan inn at Tranent.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
